subject: Design
title: The System Usability Scale: A Score for UX
description: A quick, practical guide to The System Usability Scale: A Score for UX.

hook.text: Can you measure how usable something feels? In 1986, John Brooke created a 10-question test that does.

buildup.text: The System Usability Scale (SUS) asks users to rate statements like 'I found this system easy to use.'

discovery.text: SUS produces a score from 0-100. Anything above 68 is above average. Below 50 is unusable.

twist.text: Despite being nearly 40 years old, SUS is still the most widely used usability metric in the industry.

climax.text: SUS gave designers a common language to compare usability across products and versions.

punchline.text: Ten questions. One score. Thirty-eight years of relevance.

quiz.question: What does the System Usability Scale measure?
